generatedSources.name: #utility.yul

deployedGeneratedSources.name: #utility.yul

devdoc.details: This is an implementation of the Bancor formula with slight modifications.

calculatePriceForNTokens(uint32,uint256,.details: Try to compute the price to purchage n token. This is the modified component in addition  to the two original functions below. Formula: Return = _reserveBalance * (((_amount / _supply + 1) ^ (MAX_RESERVE_RATIO / _reserveRatio)) - 1)

params._amount: number to tokens one wishes to purchase
params._reserveRatio: the reserve ratio in the bancor curve.

calculatePurchaseReturn(uint32,uint256,u.details: given a continuous token supply, reserve token balance, reserve ratio, and a deposit amount (in the reserve token), calculates the return for a given conversion (in the continuous token) Formula: Return = _supply * ((1 + _depositAmount / _reserveBalance) ^ (_reserveRatio / MAX_RESERVE_RATIO) - 1)

calculateSaleReturn(uint32,uint256,uint3.details: given a continuous token supply, reserve token balance, reserve ratio and a sell amount (in the continuous token), calculates the return for a given conversion (in the reserve token) Formula: Return = _reserveBalance * (1 - (1 - _sellAmount / _supply) ^ (1 / (_reserveRatio / MAX_RESERVE_RATIO)))

params._reserveRatio: constant reserve ratio, represented in ppm, 1-1000000
params._sellAmount: sell amount, in the continuous token itself

devdoc.title: BancorBondingCurve

userdoc.notice: General rule of computation we will use here: token amount will be passed in as uint32, since tokens we have are indivisible they will be converted to uint256 in function for safemath computation if a uint32 variable needs to be returned, it will be computed as uint256 value, then casted explicitly
